The claim was made by Kirsten Gillibrand: a Democrat from New York, during an interview on Good Morning America.
The claim was contradicted by two politi: 3. Three political scientists conducted a study analyzing the actions of members of Congress, including travel, co-sponsorship of bills, procedural votes, and offering amendments. The study found that women in Congress did not exhibit more bipartisan tendencies or a greater willingness to collaborate.
Another study conducted by Quorum: a technology company, found that women senators gained more bipartisan co-sponsors for their bills and passed more bills over a seven-year period compared to men. However, they did not pass more bills overall.
